Award.AwardTitle: Extra-transcriptional Regulatory Functions of the RNA Polymerase III System

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit:
Within the nuclei of eukaryotic cells, genomic DNA is associated with numerous different proteins to form a structure referred to as chromatin. These proteins can be either directly bound to DNA, or bound via interactions with other proteins. These proteins can have a variety of influences on which genes are expressed in different cells, and also govern the amount of gene expression under different environmental conditions. The research described here focuses on how proteins of the RNA Polymerase III (Pol III) system affect expression of other genes that are transcribed by other eukaryotic RNA polymerases. Previous work established that tRNA genes (tDNAs), with their assembled RNA Polymerase III (Pol III) protein complexes, function as barriers to the spread of repressive chromatin in yeast, and as insulators to gene activation. These results indicated that Pol III complexes are involved in demarcating the boundaries of chromosomal domains. In this project, the idea that Pol III genes exhibit additional 'extra-transcriptional' functions beyond their role in synthesizing small RNA molecules will be further examined. Recent data suggests that Pol III complexes can have direct effects on the level of Pol II transcription, and that Pol III complexes also prevent inappropriate elongation by Pol II. This project will also test hypotheses to explain the mechanism that allows Pol III complexes to function in these capacities. Finally, the research will evaluate which proteins of the Pol III complex are necessary and sufficient for such functions.

Broader impacts:
From a scientific perspective, the significance of this study is to determine whether Pol III complex proteins have general extra-transcriptional functions in yeast, which may have far-reaching implications in the regulation of gene expression in other eukaryotes. In addition to direct scientific advancement, the research will have a significant impact in education, allowing the training of graduate students, and the nurturing of research interests of promising undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the proposal was to identify and characterize what we refer to as "extra-transcriptional functions" of the RNA polymerase III system. While many genes are studied in isolation, our past results have shown that the activity of particular genes had unanticipated affects on neighboring genes. During this funding period, we have uncovered additional cases of these effects, and have shown that that may be important in the normal regulation of the neighboring gene. More important, we show that disruption of the function of some gene regulatory regions can have profound negative effects on their neiboring genes, and that such effects shown in yeast may be extrapolated to other living systems, even humans. 

We published three manuscripts during the course of this funding, and have a fourth submitted for publication. The resutls detail a particular case where one transfer RNA gene promoter is critical in protecting a neighboring gene from misregulation. We extended this concept by performing a genome-wide analysis, which uncovered many other instances where transfer RNA genes have either positive or negative effects on their neighbors.

From the training perspective, my lab has done diligence in providing opportunities to underrepresented groups in the sciences. I have trained two female Ph.D. students during this award, and each moved on to excellent post-doctoral positions at Yale and Emory Universities. I am especially proud of my undergraduate trainees, which numbered seven during this grant award. Two have moved on to graduate programs. Chance Nowak was in my lab for two years, and is currently in a synthetic biology Ph.D. program. Of particular note is Lauren Panny, who was first an Art major turned Biology major, and after 2-1/2 years in my lab pursued graduate school, where she began a program related to biodefense in the Fall of 2018. A current undergraduate, Laurie Lyon is now applying to graduate programs in vaccine research. I feel that these students are our future, and was honored to have been able to help them find their passion in research.
